title: John Chapter 15 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on John chapter 15 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: John Chapter 15 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of John Chapter 15.

questions.question: Who is described as the true vine in John 15?
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus
questions.explanation: John 15:1 states, 'I am the true vine,' referring to Jesus.

questions.question: According to John 15:2, what happens to every branch that does not bear fruit?
questions.correctAnswer: It is taken away
questions.explanation: John 15:2 states that every branch that beareth not fruit is taken away.

questions.question: What makes the branches clean according to John 15:3?
questions.correctAnswer: The word spoken by Jesus
questions.explanation: John 15:3 says, 'Now ye are clean through the word which I have spoken unto you.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'Abide in me, and I in you. As the branch cannot bear fruit of itself, except it abide in the _____; no more can ye, except ye abide in me.'
questions.correctAnswer: vine
questions.explanation: John 15:4 says a branch must abide in the vine to bear fruit.

questions.question: What does Jesus say about those who do not abide in him in John 15:6?
options: They are cast forth, wither, and are burned
questions.correctAnswer: They are cast forth, wither, and are burned
questions.explanation: John 15:6 states that if a man does not abide in Jesus, he is cast forth as a branch and burned.

questions.question: According to John 15:7, what will happen if you abide in Jesus and His words abide in you?
options: You shall ask what you will, and it shall be done
questions.correctAnswer: You shall ask what you will, and it shall be done
questions.explanation: John 15:7 promises that abiding in Jesus and His words allows your prayers to be answered.

questions.question: What glorifies the Father according to John 15:8?
questions.correctAnswer: Bearing much fruit
questions.explanation: John 15:8 says the Father is glorified when you bear much fruit.

questions.question: How does Jesus describe his love for us in John 15:9?
options: As the Father hath loved him
As a mother loves her child
As a shepherd loves his sheep
As a friend loves a friend
questions.correctAnswer: As the Father hath loved him
questions.explanation: John 15:9 states Jesus loves us as the Father has loved Him.

questions.question: What is the commandment Jesus gives in John 15:12?
options: That ye love one another as I have loved you
That ye go and make disciples
questions.correctAnswer: That ye love one another as I have loved you
questions.explanation: John 15:12 commands loving one another as Jesus has loved us.

questions.question: What is the greatest love according to John 15:13?
options: Laying down one’s life for friends
questions.correctAnswer: Laying down one’s life for friends
questions.explanation: John 15:13 explains the greatest love is laying down life for friends.

questions.question: True or False: Jesus calls his followers servants because they do not know what their lord does.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: John 15:15 says Jesus calls them friends, not servants, because servants do not know what their lord does.

questions.question: True or False: According to John 15:18, the world will love Jesus’ followers because they are of the world.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: John 15:18 states the world hated Jesus before it hated his followers, implying they are not loved because they are not of the world.

questions.question: True or False: In John 15:26, the Comforter is sent from the Father and is called the Spirit of truth.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: John 15:26 identifies the Comforter as the Spirit of truth sent from the Father.

questions.question: Who does Jesus say has chosen his followers according to John 15:16?
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus
questions.explanation: John 15:16 says Jesus has chosen his followers, not they themselves.

questions.question: According to John 15:20, what happens to those who have persecuted Jesus?
options: They will also persecute his followers
questions.correctAnswer: They will also persecute his followers
questions.explanation: John 15:20 states if they have persecuted Jesus, they will also persecute his followers.

medium.title: John Chapter 15 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from John Chapter 15 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does John 15 teach us about the importance of abiding in Christ for spiritual fruitfulness?
options: We must remain connected to Christ as branches to the vine to bear fruit.
We can bear much fruit by our own strength without Christ.
Fruitfulness is unrelated to our relationship with Christ.
Only some branches need to abide in the vine to produce fruit.
questions.correctAnswer: We must remain connected to Christ as branches to the vine to bear fruit.
questions.explanation: John 15:4-5 teaches that just as branches cannot bear fruit unless they abide in the vine, believers cannot bear fruit unless they remain in Christ. Verses 2 and 8 also emphasize pruning and glorifying God through fruitfulness.

questions.question: A fellow believer feels discouraged because they are not seeing much fruit in their life. According to John 15, what biblical truth about pruning would encourage them?
options: God prunes fruitful branches to help them bear more fruit.
Branches that bear fruit are left alone without pruning.
Pruning is a punishment for failure to bear fruit.
Only unfruitful branches are kept and nurtured.
questions.correctAnswer: God prunes fruitful branches to help them bear more fruit.
questions.explanation: John 15:2 explains that God purges or prunes branches that bear fruit so they may bring forth more fruit, indicating God's discipline is for growth, not punishment.

questions.question: What assurance does John 15 give about prayer to those who abide in Christ and have His words abide in them?
options: They may ask what they will, and it shall be done unto them.
They will only receive what they deserve.
They should pray only for their own needs.
Prayer is optional for those who abide in Christ.
questions.correctAnswer: They may ask what they will, and it shall be done unto them.
questions.explanation: John 15:7 promises that if believers abide in Christ and His words abide in them, their prayers will be answered according to God's will, showing the power of prayer rooted in relationship.

questions.question: How does John 15 connect bearing fruit with glorifying God and being recognized as Jesus' disciples?
options: Bearing much fruit glorifies the Father and identifies us as His disciples.
Fruit-bearing is unrelated to glorifying God or discipleship.
Only spiritual gifts glorify God, not fruitfulness.
Discipleship is shown by knowledge, not fruit-bearing.
questions.correctAnswer: Bearing much fruit glorifies the Father and identifies us as His disciples.
questions.explanation: John 15:8 states that bearing much fruit glorifies God the Father and confirms that we are Jesus' disciples, emphasizing the importance of visible spiritual fruit.

questions.question: A believer struggles to love others consistently. According to John 15, what commandment would you share to guide them?
options: Love one another as I have loved you.
Love only those who love you.
Love is only for friends, not enemies.
questions.correctAnswer: Love one another as I have loved you.
questions.explanation: John 15:12 and 17 command believers to love each other just as Jesus loved them, making love the defining mark of Christian life and obedience.

questions.question: What is the greatest demonstration of love according to John 15?
options: Laying down one's life for one's friends.
questions.correctAnswer: Laying down one's life for one's friends.
questions.explanation: John 15:13 teaches that the greatest love is shown by laying down one's life for friends, highlighting sacrificial love as the highest standard.

questions.question: How does John 15 describe the relationship between Jesus and His followers, contrasting it with servants?
options: Jesus calls them friends because He has revealed the Father's will to them.
Jesus calls them servants because they must obey without understanding.
They are strangers to Jesus' plans.
They are merely servants without intimacy.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus calls them friends because He has revealed the Father's will to them.
questions.explanation: John 15:15 explains that Jesus no longer calls believers servants but friends, because He has shared with them all that He has heard from the Father, indicating intimacy and revelation.

questions.question: According to John 15, why does the world hate Jesus’ followers?
options: Because they are not of the world, just as Jesus was chosen out of the world.
Because they have done evil deeds.
Because they conform to the world's standards.
questions.correctAnswer: Because they are not of the world, just as Jesus was chosen out of the world.
questions.explanation: John 15:18-19 states that the world hates believers because they are not of the world, just as it hated Jesus, who was chosen out of the world by the Father.

questions.question: What encouragement does John 15 offer about persecution to believers?
options: If they persecuted Jesus, they will also persecute His followers.
Persecution means God has abandoned them.
Persecution is a sign of failure.
questions.correctAnswer: If they persecuted Jesus, they will also persecute His followers.
questions.explanation: John 15:20 reminds believers that since Jesus was persecuted, His followers can expect similar treatment, encouraging endurance and faithfulness.

questions.question: How does John 15 teach us about the origin and purpose of choosing believers?
options: Jesus chose believers to go and bear fruit that remains.
Believers choose Jesus for their own benefit.
Believers are chosen for worldly success.
Choosing is based on human merit.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus chose believers to go and bear fruit that remains.
questions.explanation: John 15:16 states that Jesus chose believers and appointed them to bear lasting fruit, emphasizing divine initiative and purpose in the Christian life.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with joy in their spiritual walk. Based on John 15, what truth would encourage them?
options: Jesus spoke these things so that His joy would remain in believers and their joy be full.
Joy comes only from material blessings.
Joy is unrelated to abiding in Jesus.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus spoke these things so that His joy would remain in believers and their joy be full.
questions.explanation: John 15:11 shows that Jesus shared His teachings so believers might have His enduring and complete joy, encouraging them to abide in Him.

questions.question: True or False: According to John 15, a branch that does not bear fruit is kept and cherished by the husbandman.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: John 15:2 and 6 explain that unfruitful branches are taken away and wither, then gathered and burned, indicating they are not kept but removed.

questions.question: True or False: John 15 teaches that hatred toward believers is a new experience, not something Jesus also faced.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: John 15:18-20 clearly states that the world hated Jesus before it hated His followers, showing believers share in His experience of hatred.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: John 15:1 states, "I am the true ____, and my Father is the husbandman."
questions.correctAnswer: vine
questions.explanation: John 15:1 uses the metaphor of the vine to illustrate the relationship between Jesus, the Father, and believers, emphasizing spiritual connection and growth.

questions.question: According to John 15, what is the condition for believers to abide in Jesus’ love?
questions.correctAnswer: Keeping His commandments.
questions.explanation: John 15:10 teaches that abiding in Jesus’ love depends on obeying His commandments, just as He obeyed the Father to abide in His love.

hard.title: John Chapter 15 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from John Chapter 15.

questions.question: In John 15:1, Jesus refers to Himself as the 'true vine.' What Old Testament imagery is He drawing upon to convey this metaphor?
options: The vineyard imagery of Israel in Psalm 80
The pillar of cloud and fire in Exodus 13
The manna in the wilderness in Exodus 16
questions.correctAnswer: The vineyard imagery of Israel in Psalm 80
questions.explanation: John 15:1 uses the metaphor of the vine, which alludes to Old Testament passages such as Psalm 80:8-16 and Isaiah 5:1-7, where Israel is portrayed as a vineyard or vine cultivated by God.

questions.question: According to John 15:2, what is the purpose of God purging the fruitful branches?
options: So that they may bring forth more fruit
To prepare the branches for harvest
To separate them from the vine
questions.correctAnswer: So that they may bring forth more fruit
questions.explanation: John 15:2 explains that God prunes fruitful branches to increase their productivity, which is a metaphor for spiritual growth and sanctification.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from John 15:4: 'Abide in me, and I in you. As the branch cannot bear fruit of itself, except it abide in the ____; no more can ye, except ye abide in me.'
questions.correctAnswer: vine
questions.explanation: The metaphor in John 15:4 centers on the vine and branches, emphasizing the necessity of remaining connected to Jesus, the true vine, to bear fruit.

questions.question: What does Jesus say in John 15:5 is impossible without abiding in Him?
options: To enter the kingdom of heaven
questions.correctAnswer: To bear fruit
questions.explanation: John 15:5 states that without Jesus, the true vine, one cannot bear fruit, which symbolizes spiritual productivity and life.

questions.question: True or False: According to John 15:6, a branch that does not abide in the vine is gathered and used for building purposes.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: John 15:6 explains that branches not abiding in the vine are gathered and cast into the fire to be burned, symbolizing judgment, not building.

questions.question: According to John 15:7, what condition must be met for Jesus' followers' prayers to be answered?
options: If ye abide in me, and my words abide in you
If ye gather in His name
questions.correctAnswer: If ye abide in me, and my words abide in you
questions.explanation: John 15:7 emphasizes the necessity of abiding in Jesus and His words remaining in believers as the condition for answered prayers.

questions.question: In John 15:8, what is glorified when believers bear much fruit?
questions.correctAnswer: The Father
questions.explanation: John 15:8 clearly states that the Father is glorified when His disciples bear much fruit, indicating that productive discipleship honors God.

questions.question: What commandment does Jesus give in John 15:12 that reflects the central ethical teaching of the New Testament?
options: That ye love one another, as I have loved you
That ye keep the Sabbath holy
That ye preach to all nations
questions.correctAnswer: That ye love one another, as I have loved you
questions.explanation: John 15:12 commands love among believers, mirroring Jesus' own love, which is foundational throughout the New Testament ethics.

questions.question: John 15:13 speaks of the greatest love. How is this love described?
options: Laying down one's life for friends
questions.correctAnswer: Laying down one's life for friends
questions.explanation: John 15:13 highlights self-sacrificial love as the highest form of love, prefiguring Jesus' own sacrifice on the cross.

questions.question: According to John 15:15, why does Jesus call His disciples 'friends' instead of 'servants'?
options: Because He has made known to them all things He heard from the Father
Because they have obeyed all His commands
Because they are part of the Jewish leadership
questions.correctAnswer: Because He has made known to them all things He heard from the Father
questions.explanation: John 15:15 explains that Jesus elevates His disciples to friends by revealing divine truths to them, showing intimacy beyond mere servanthood.

questions.question: Who does Jesus say has chosen the disciples in John 15:16, and what is the purpose of this choosing?
options: Jesus has chosen them to go and bring forth fruit
The disciples have chosen Jesus to lead them
The Father has chosen them to build the temple
The crowds have chosen them to be rulers
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus has chosen them to go and bring forth fruit
questions.explanation: John 15:16 states Jesus chose His disciples so that they would bear lasting spiritual fruit, emphasizing divine initiative and mission.

questions.question: True or False: John 15:18 teaches that the world will love Jesus' followers because they are of the world.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: John 15:18 teaches the opposite: the world hates Jesus' followers because they are not of the world, reflecting the conflict between the kingdom of God and worldly values.

questions.question: What reason does John 15:21 give for the persecution of Jesus' followers?
options: Because they know not Him that sent Jesus
Because they refuse to pay taxes
questions.correctAnswer: Because they know not Him that sent Jesus
questions.explanation: John 15:21 explains followers are persecuted due to ignorance of God who sent Jesus, indicating spiritual blindness behind hostility.

questions.question: According to John 15:25, what Old Testament law is fulfilled by those who hate Jesus without cause?
options: They hated me without a cause
questions.correctAnswer: They hated me without a cause
questions.explanation: John 15:25 cites Psalm 35:19 and 69:4, referencing the prophetic fulfillment of unjust hatred towards Jesus.

questions.question: What role does the 'Comforter' play according to John 15:26?
options: The Spirit of truth who testifies of Jesus
A political leader who defends the disciples
A prophet who predicts the future
questions.correctAnswer: The Spirit of truth who testifies of Jesus
questions.explanation: John 15:26 describes the Comforter (Holy Spirit) as the Spirit of truth sent from the Father to testify about Jesus, emphasizing the Spirit's revelatory role.

theological.title: John Chapter 15 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from John Chapter 15 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In John 15:1, Jesus declares Himself as the true vine. What theological significance does this imagery carry regarding Christ's relationship to believers?
options: Christ is the source of spiritual life and sustenance for believers
Christ is a distant ruler who commands from afar
Believers are independent from Christ for their spiritual growth
Christ is only a symbol without real power
questions.correctAnswer: Christ is the source of spiritual life and sustenance for believers
questions.explanation: John 15:1 presents Jesus as the true vine, emphasizing that believers (branches) derive their spiritual life and fruitfulness from Him. This aligns with Scriptures like Isaiah 5:1-7 where Israel is depicted as a vine cared for by God, Psalm 80:8-16 where God is the vinedresser, and Hebrews 12:2 which calls Jesus the author and finisher of faith, indicating reliance on Him for spiritual vitality.

questions.question: According to John 15:2, what does the Father do to every branch that does not bear fruit?
questions.correctAnswer: He taketh it away
questions.explanation: John 15:2 clearly states that every branch not bearing fruit is taken away by the Father, symbolizing divine judgment upon unfruitfulness. This is consistent with Ezekiel 15:2-6 where unproductive wood is burned, Psalm 1:3 which contrasts fruitful and unfruitful lives, and Matthew 3:10 where unfruitful trees are cut down, highlighting God's holiness and requirement for fruitfulness.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'Abide in me, and I in you. As the branch cannot bear fruit of itself, except it abide in the _____; no more can ye, except ye abide in me.'
questions.correctAnswer: vine
questions.explanation: John 15:4 uses the vine and branch metaphor to teach that spiritual fruitfulness depends on abiding in Christ (the vine). This concept is echoed in Romans 11:17-24 where branches are grafted into the olive tree, Psalm 80:8-9 describing God as the vinedresser, and 1 Corinthians 3:6-7 emphasizing God’s role in growth.

questions.question: What does Jesus say about the ability to produce fruit apart from Him in John 15:5?
options: Without me ye can do nothing
You can bear some fruit by your own effort
Fruitfulness is unrelated to abiding in Christ
questions.correctAnswer: Without me ye can do nothing
questions.explanation: John 15:5 teaches the absolute dependence on Christ for spiritual productivity. This is consistent with 2 Corinthians 3:5 which says our sufficiency is from God, Philippians 4:13 where strength comes through Christ, and Colossians 1:17 affirming Christ’s sustenance of all things.

questions.question: According to John 15:6, what happens to a man who does not abide in Jesus?
options: He is cast forth, withered, gathered, and burned
He is forgiven and restored immediately
questions.correctAnswer: He is cast forth, withered, gathered, and burned
questions.explanation: John 15:6 describes judgment on those who do not abide in Christ, symbolized by being cut off and burned. This aligns with Matthew 7:19 about trees that do not bear good fruit being cut down, Psalm 37:20 describing the fate of the wicked, and Malachi 4:1 which depicts unrepentant sinners burned like stubble.

questions.question: What promise is given in John 15:7 for those who abide in Jesus and His words abide in them?
options: They shall ask what they will, and it shall be done unto them
They will be free from sin
questions.correctAnswer: They shall ask what they will, and it shall be done unto them
questions.explanation: John 15:7 promises answered prayer for those abiding in Christ and His word, emphasizing spiritual alignment with God's will. This is supported by 1 John 5:14-15 about confident prayer, Matthew 21:22 which links faith and answered prayer, and James 4:3 warning against selfish requests.

questions.question: How is the Father glorified according to John 15:8?
questions.correctAnswer: By bearing much fruit
questions.explanation: John 15:8 teaches that glorifying the Father occurs through disciples bearing fruit, which reflects Christ's life in them. This corresponds with Matthew 5:16 about letting your light shine, Ephesians 2:10 regarding good works prepared by God, and Psalm 92:12-14 describing the righteous bearing fruit.

questions.question: What commandment does Jesus give in John 15:12?
options: Love one another as I have loved you
questions.correctAnswer: Love one another as I have loved you
questions.explanation: John 15:12 commands love modeled on Christ’s sacrificial love. This reflects Leviticus 19:18’s call to love your neighbor, Romans 13:8-10 on love fulfilling the law, 1 John 4:7-12 emphasizing love as from God, and Matthew 22:37-40 summarizing the greatest commandments.

questions.question: According to John 15:13, what is the greatest form of love?
options: Laying down one's life for friends
questions.correctAnswer: Laying down one's life for friends
questions.explanation: John 15:13 states the greatest love is sacrificial death for friends, exemplified supremely by Christ. This is consistent with Romans 5:8 showing Christ’s love in dying for sinners, 1 John 3:16 on laying down life for brethren, and Ephesians 5:2 calling believers to walk in love as Christ did.

questions.question: In John 15:15, why does Jesus call His disciples friends rather than servants?
options: Because He has made known to them all things heard from the Father
Because servants are equal to masters
questions.correctAnswer: Because He has made known to them all things heard from the Father
questions.explanation: John 15:15 highlights the intimacy and revelation granted to disciples, making them friends rather than mere servants. This aligns with Exodus 33:11 describing Moses speaking to God face to face, James 2:23 calling Abraham God’s friend, and Hebrews 1:1-2 showing God’s final revelation in Christ to His friends.

questions.question: What does Jesus say about the origin of the disciples' choosing in John 15:16?
options: Jesus chose them, not the other way around
They chose Jesus by their own will
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus chose them, not the other way around
questions.explanation: John 15:16 affirms divine election in the calling of disciples, emphasizing God's sovereign initiative. This corresponds with Ephesians 1:4-5 on God choosing believers before the world, Romans 8:29-30 on predestination, and John 6:44 where no one can come unless drawn by the Father.

questions.question: According to John 15:18, why does the world hate the disciples?
questions.correctAnswer: Because it hated Jesus first
questions.explanation: John 15:18 teaches that the hatred disciples face is a continuation of the world's hatred for Jesus. This is consistent with Psalm 69:4 predicting hatred without cause, 1 John 3:13 on hatred as evidence of spiritual death, and Matthew 10:22 about being hated for Jesus' name's sake.

questions.question: What warning does Jesus give in John 15:20 regarding persecution?
options: If they persecuted Jesus, they will also persecute you
Persecution will never come to you
Persecution is a sign of failure
questions.correctAnswer: If they persecuted Jesus, they will also persecute you
questions.explanation: John 15:20 warns disciples about suffering similar to Christ’s persecution, signifying faithfulness. This aligns with 2 Timothy 3:12 stating all who desire to live godly will suffer, Acts 14:22 encouraging perseverance through tribulation, and 1 Peter 4:12-16 about rejoicing in suffering for Christ.

questions.question: According to John 15:22, what is the consequence if Jesus had not come and spoken to the people?
options: They would not have had sin
They would have understood the law
questions.correctAnswer: They would not have had sin
questions.explanation: John 15:22 explains that Christ’s coming brings accountability and awareness of sin. This corresponds with Romans 5:13 on sin not imputed without law, Hebrews 9:14 showing Christ’s blood dealing with sin, and John 3:19 describing light exposing sin.

questions.question: Who is the Comforter mentioned in John 15:26, and what is His role?
options: The Spirit of truth who proceeds from the Father and testifies of Jesus
An angel sent to guide the disciples
A prophet who will come after Jesus
A human teacher appointed by Jesus
questions.correctAnswer: The Spirit of truth who proceeds from the Father and testifies of Jesus
questions.explanation: John 15:26 identifies the Comforter as the Spirit of truth sent by the Father to testify about Jesus. This is consistent with John 14:26 describing the Holy Spirit teaching and reminding, Acts 1:8 on receiving power from the Spirit, and Romans 8:16 affirming the Spirit’s witness to believers.
